chunks.content: # ‚öóÔ∏è Chemistry Complete Guide - All Topics ## Table of Contents 1. [Atomic Structure](#atomic-structure) 2. [Chemical Bonding](#chemical-bonding) 3. [Chemical Reactions](#chemical-reactions) 4. [Acids, Bases & pH](#acids-bases--ph) 5. [The Mole Concept](#the-mole-concept) 6. [Stoichiometry](#stoichiometry) 7. [Gas Laws](#gas-laws) 8. [Thermochemistry](#thermochemistry) 9. [Chemical Equilibrium](#chemical-equilibrium) 10. [Organic Chemistry](#organic-chemistry) 11. [Electrochemistry](#electrochemistry) 12. [Periodic Table](#periodic-table) --- # ‚öõÔ∏è Atomic Structure ## Atomic Components **The atom consists of:** **1. Protons** ($p^+$) - Location: Nucleus - Charge: $+1$ - Mass: $\approx 1$ amu **2. Neutrons** ($n^0$) - Location: Nucleus - Charge: $0$ (neutral) - Mass: $\approx 1$ amu **3. Electrons** ($e^-$) - Location: Electron shells - Charge: $-1$ - Mass: $\approx \frac{1}{1836}$ amu (negligible) --- ## Atomic Number and Mass Number **Atomic Number** ($Z$): $$\boxed{Z = \text{Number of protons}}$$ **Mass Number** ($A$): $$\boxed{A = \text{Protons} + \text{Neutrons}}$$ **Number of neutrons:** $$\boxed{N = A - Z}$$ **Standard notation:** $$\boxed{^{A}_{Z}X}$$ **Example:** Carbon-12 $$^{12}_{6}C$$ - Protons: $Z = 6$ - Neutrons: $N = 12 - 6 = 6$ - Electrons: $6$ (in neutral atom) --- ## Isotopes **Definition:** Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons **Example:** Carbon isotopes - $^{12}C$ (Carbon-12): 6 protons, 6 neutrons - $^{13}C$ (Carbon-13): 6 protons, 7 neutrons - $^{14}C$ (Carbon-14): 6 protons, 8 neutrons (radioactive) **Relative Atomic Mass:** $$\boxed{A_r = \frac{\sum(\text{isotope mass} \times \text{abundance})}{100}}$$ **Example:** Chlorine - $^{35}Cl$: 75% abundance, mass = 35 - $^{37}Cl$: 25% abundance, mass = 37 $$A_r = \frac{(35 \times 75) + (37 \times 25)}{100} = \frac{2625 + 925}{100} = 35.5$$ --- ## Electron Configuration **Rules:** 1. **Aufbau Principle:** Fill lowest energy levels first 2. **Pauli Exclusion:** Max 2 electrons per orbital 3. **Hund's Rule:** Fill orbitals singly before pairing **Electron shell capacity:** $$\boxed{\text{Max electrons} = 2n^2}$$ Where $n$ = shell number **Shells:** - $n=1$: max $2(1)^2 = 2$ electrons - $n=2$: max $2(2)^2 = 8$ electrons - $n=3$: max $2(3)^2 = 18$ electrons **Examples:** **Carbon (6 electrons):** $$1s^2 \, 2s^2 \, 2p^2$$ or: $2, 4$ (shell notation) **Oxygen (8 electrons):** $$1s^2 \, 2s^2 \, 2p^4$$ or: $2, 6$ **Sodium (11 electrons):** $$1s^2 \, 2s^2 \, 2p^6 \, 3s^1$$ or: $2, 8, 1$ --- # üîó Chemical Bonding ## Types of Chemical Bonds ### 1. Ionic Bonding **Definition:** Transfer of electrons from metal to non-metal **Formation:** $$\text{Metal} - e^- \rightarrow \text{Metal}^+ \text{ (cation)}$$ $$\text{Non-metal} + e^- \rightarrow \text{Non-metal}^- \text{ (anion)}$$ **Example:** Sodium chloride (NaCl) $$Na \rightarrow Na^+ + e^-$$ $$Cl + e^- \rightarrow Cl^-$$ $$Na^+ + Cl^- \rightarrow NaCl$$ **Properties:** - High melting/boiling points - Conduct electricity when molten/dissolved - Form crystalline structures --- ### 2. Covalent Bonding **Definition:** Sharing of electron pairs between non-metals **Single bond:** Share 1 pair (2 electrons) $$H \cdot + \cdot H \rightarrow H:H \text{ or } H-H$$ **Double bond:** Share 2 pairs (4 electrons) $$O::O \text{ or } O=O$$ **Triple bond:** Share 3 pairs (6 electrons) $$N:::N \text{ or } N \equiv N$$ **Examples:** **Water** ($H_2O$): $$H-O-H$$ 2 single bonds **Carbon dioxide** ($CO_2$): $$O=C=O$$ 2 double bonds **Nitrogen gas** ($N_2$): $$N \equiv N$$ 1 triple bond --- ### 3. Metallic Bonding **Definition:** "Sea of
chunks.subject: Chemistry Complete

chunks.content: $$O::O \text{ or } O=O$$ **Triple bond:** Share 3 pairs (6 electrons) $$N:::N \text{ or } N \equiv N$$ **Examples:** **Water** ($H_2O$): $$H-O-H$$ 2 single bonds **Carbon dioxide** ($CO_2$): $$O=C=O$$ 2 double bonds **Nitrogen gas** ($N_2$): $$N \equiv N$$ 1 triple bond --- ### 3. Metallic Bonding **Definition:** "Sea of electrons" shared among metal atoms **Structure:** $$\text{Metal}^+ \text{ ions in sea of delocalized } e^-$$ **Properties:** - Good electrical conductivity - Good thermal conductivity - Malleable and ductile - Lustrous (shiny) --- ## Electronegativity **Definition:** Ability to attract electrons in a bond **Pauling scale:** 0 to 4 **Most electronegative:** F (Fluorine) = 4.0 **Least electronegative:** Fr (Francium) = 0.7 **Electronegativity difference ($\Delta EN$):** $$\Delta EN < 0.5 \rightarrow \text{Non-polar covalent}$$ $$0.5 < \Delta EN < 1.7 \rightarrow \text{Polar covalent}$$ $$\Delta EN > 1.7 \rightarrow \text{Ionic}$$ --- ## Lewis Structures **Steps:** 1. Count total valence electrons 2. Draw skeletal structure 3. Complete octets (8 electrons) 4. Form multiple bonds if needed **Example:** $CO_2$ **Step 1:** Total electrons - C: 4 valence - O: 6 valence √ó 2 = 12 - Total: $4 + 12 = 16$ electrons **Step 2-4:** Structure $$O=C=O$$ --- # ‚öóÔ∏è Chemical Reactions ## Types of Chemical Reactions ### 1. Synthesis (Combination) $$\boxed{A + B \rightarrow AB}$$ **Example:** $$2H_2 + O_2 \rightarrow 2H_2O$$ --- ### 2. Decomposition $$\boxed{AB \rightarrow A + B}$$ **Example:** $$2H_2O \xrightarrow{\text{electricity}} 2H_2 + O_2$$ --- ### 3. Single Displacement $$\boxed{A + BC \rightarrow AC + B}$$ **Example:** $$Zn + 2HCl \rightarrow ZnCl_2 + H_2$$ --- ### 4. Double Displacement $$\boxed{AB + CD \rightarrow AD + CB}$$ **Example:** $$AgNO_3 + NaCl \rightarrow AgCl \downarrow + NaNO_3$$ --- ### 5. Combustion $$\boxed{\text{Fuel} + O_2 \rightarrow CO_2 + H_2O + \text{Energy}}$$ **Example:** $$CH_4 + 2O_2 \rightarrow CO_2 + 2H_2O$$ --- ## Balancing Chemical Equations **Law of Conservation of Mass:** $$\boxed{\text{Mass of reactants} = \text{Mass of products}}$$ **Steps:** 1. Write unbalanced equation 2. Count atoms on each side 3. Add coefficients to balance 4. Check your work **Example:** Combustion of propane **Unbalanced:** $$C_3H_8 + O_2 \rightarrow CO_2 + H_2O$$ **Balanced:** $$C_3H_8 + 5O_2 \rightarrow 3CO_2 + 4H_2O$$ **Check:** - C: $3 = 3$ ‚úì - H: $8 = 8$ ‚úì - O: $10 = 10$ ‚úì --- # üî¥üîµ Acids, Bases & pH ## Definitions ### Arrhenius Definition **Acid:** Produces $H^+$ in water $$HCl \rightarrow H^+ + Cl^-$$ **Base:** Produces $OH^-$ in water $$NaOH \rightarrow Na^+ + OH^-$$ --- ### Br√∏nsted-Lowry Definition **Acid:** Proton ($H^+$) donor $$HA \rightarrow H^+ + A^-$$ **Base:** Proton ($H^+$) acceptor $$B + H^+ \rightarrow BH^+$$ --- ## pH Scale **Definition:** $$\boxed{pH = -\log[H^+]}$$ **Range:** 0 to 14 $$pH < 7 \rightarrow \text{Acidic}$$ $$pH = 7 \rightarrow \text{Neutral}$$ $$pH > 7 \rightarrow \text{Basic (Alkaline)}$$ --- ## pH Calculations **Example 1:** Find pH of $[H^+] = 1 \times 10^{-3}$ M $$pH = -\log(1 \times 10^{-3}) = -(-3) = 3$$ **Example 2:** Find $[H^+]$ if pH = 5 $$[H^+] = 10^{-pH} = 10^{-5} = 0.00001 \text{ M}$$ --- ## pOH and Relationship $$\boxed{pOH = -\log[OH^-]}$$ $$\boxed{pH
chunks.subject: Chemistry Complete

chunks.content: --- ## pH Calculations **Example 1:** Find pH of $[H^+] = 1 \times 10^{-3}$ M $$pH = -\log(1 \times 10^{-3}) = -(-3) = 3$$ **Example 2:** Find $[H^+]$ if pH = 5 $$[H^+] = 10^{-pH} = 10^{-5} = 0.00001 \text{ M}$$ --- ## pOH and Relationship $$\boxed{pOH = -\log[OH^-]}$$ $$\boxed{pH + pOH = 14}$$ $$\boxed{[H^+] \times [OH^-] = 1 \times 10^{-14}}$$ **Example:** If pH = 3, find pOH $$pOH = 14 - 3 = 11$$ --- ## Strong vs Weak Acids/Bases **Strong acids** (100% ionized): - $HCl$ (Hydrochloric acid) - $H_2SO_4$ (Sulfuric acid) - $HNO_3$ (Nitric acid) **Weak acids** (partially ionized): - $CH_3COOH$ (Acetic acid) - $H_2CO_3$ (Carbonic acid) **Strong bases:** - $NaOH$ (Sodium hydroxide) - $KOH$ (Potassium hydroxide) **Weak bases:** - $NH_3$ (Ammonia) --- ## Neutralization Reactions $$\boxed{\text{Acid} + \text{Base} \rightarrow \text{Salt} + \text{Water}}$$ **Example:** $$HCl + NaOH \rightarrow NaCl + H_2O$$ **Net ionic equation:** $$H^+ + OH^- \rightarrow H_2O$$ --- # üßÆ The Mole Concept ## Avogadro's Number $$\boxed{N_A = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \text{ particles/mol}}$$ **1 mole contains:** $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ particles --- ## Mole Formula $$\boxed{n = \frac{m}{M}}$$ Where: - $n$ = moles (mol) - $m$ = mass (g) - $M$ = molar mass (g/mol) **Example:** Moles in 36g of water ($H_2O$) **Step 1:** Molar mass $$M = 2(1) + 16 = 18 \text{ g/mol}$$ **Step 2:** Calculate moles $$n = \frac{36}{18} = 2 \text{ mol}$$ --- ## Molar Mass Calculation $$\boxed{M = \sum (\text{atomic mass} \times \text{number of atoms})}$$ **Examples:** **$H_2SO_4$ (Sulfuric acid):** $$M = 2(1) + 32 + 4(16) = 2 + 32 + 64 = 98 \text{ g/mol}$$ **$Ca(NO_3)_2$ (Calcium nitrate):** $$M = 40 + 2[14 + 3(16)] = 40 + 2(62) = 164 \text{ g/mol}$$ --- ## Conversions **Mass ‚Üî Moles:** $$m = n \times M$$ **Moles ‚Üî Particles:** $$N = n \times N_A$$ **Moles ‚Üî Volume (gases at STP):** $$V = n \times 22.4 \text{ L}$$ --- # ‚öñÔ∏è Stoichiometry ## Mole Ratios From balanced equation: $aA + bB \rightarrow cC + dD$ $$\boxed{\frac{n_A}{a} = \frac{n_B}{b} = \frac{n_C}{c} = \frac{n_D}{d}}$$ --- ## Stoichiometry Calculations **Example:** How many grams of $H_2O$ are produced from 4g of $H_2$? **Equation:** $$2H_2 + O_2 \rightarrow 2H_2O$$ **Step 1:** Moles of $H_2$ $$n_{H_2} = \frac{4}{2} = 2 \text{ mol}$$ **Step 2:** Mole ratio $$\frac{n_{H_2}}{2} = \frac{n_{H_2O}}{2}$$ $$n_{H_2O} = 2 \text{ mol}$$ **Step 3:** Mass of $H_2O$ $$m_{H_2O} = 2 \times 18 = 36 \text{ g}$$ --- ## Limiting Reactant **Definition:** Reactant that runs out first, limiting product formation **Steps:** 1. Calculate moles of each reactant 2. Divide by stoichiometric coefficient 3. Smallest value = limiting reactant **Example:** $$N_2 + 3H_2 \rightarrow 2NH_3$$ Given: 2 mol $N_2$, 4 mol $H_2$ **For $N_2$:** $\frac{2}{1} = 2$ **For $H_2$:** $\frac{4}{3} = 1.33$ ‚Üê **Limiting!** $H_2$ is limiting reactant --- ## Percent Yield $$\boxed{\text{Percent Yield} = \frac{\text{Actual Yield}}{\text{Theoretical Yield}} \times 100\%}$$ **Example:** - Theoretical: 50g - Actual: 40g $$\text{Yield} = \frac{40}{50} \times 100\% = 80\%$$ --- # üí® Gas Laws ## Ideal Gas Law $$\boxed{PV = nRT}$$ Where: - $P$ =
chunks.subject: Chemistry Complete

chunks.content: = 1.33$ ‚Üê **Limiting!** $H_2$ is limiting reactant --- ## Percent Yield $$\boxed{\text{Percent Yield} = \frac{\text{Actual Yield}}{\text{Theoretical Yield}} \times 100\%}$$ **Example:** - Theoretical: 50g - Actual: 40g $$\text{Yield} = \frac{40}{50} \times 100\% = 80\%$$ --- # üí® Gas Laws ## Ideal Gas Law $$\boxed{PV = nRT}$$ Where: - $P$ = Pressure (atm or kPa) - $V$ = Volume (L) - $n$ = Moles (mol) - $R$ = Gas constant - $R = 0.0821 \text{ L¬∑atm/(mol¬∑K)}$ - $R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol¬∑K)}$ - $T$ = Temperature (K) **Temperature conversion:** $$\boxed{K = ¬∞C + 273.15}$$ --- ## Boyle's Law (Constant T, n) $$\boxed{P_1V_1 = P_2V_2}$$ **Pressure ‚àù $\frac{1}{\text{Volume}}$** **Example:** - $P_1 = 2$ atm, $V_1 = 5$ L - $P_2 = ?$, $V_2 = 10$ L $$2 \times 5 = P_2 \times 10$$ $$P_2 = 1 \text{ atm}$$ --- ## Charles's Law (Constant P, n) $$\boxed{\frac{V_1}{T_1} = \frac{V_2}{T_2}}$$ **Volume ‚àù Temperature (K)** --- ## Gay-Lussac's Law (Constant V, n) $$\boxed{\frac{P_1}{T_1} = \frac{P_2}{T_2}}$$ **Pressure ‚àù Temperature (K)** --- ## Combined Gas Law $$\boxed{\frac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \frac{P_2V_2}{T_2}}$$ --- ## Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures $$\boxed{P_{total} = P_1 + P_2 + P_3 + \ldots}$$ **Example:** - $P_{N_2} = 0.8$ atm - $P_{O_2} = 0.2$ atm $$P_{total} = 0.8 + 0.2 = 1.0 \text{ atm}$$ --- # üî• Thermochemistry ## Enthalpy Change $$\boxed{\Delta H = H_{products} - H_{reactants}}$$ **Exothermic:** $\Delta H < 0$ (releases heat) **Endothermic:** $\Delta H > 0$ (absorbs heat) **Example:** $$CH_4 + 2O_2 \rightarrow CO_2 + 2H_2O \quad \Delta H = -890 \text{ kJ}$$ --- ## Hess's Law $$\boxed{\Delta H_{total} = \sum \Delta H_{steps}}$$ **Example:** $$\text{Target: } C + O_2 \rightarrow CO_2$$ **Given:** $$\begin{align} C + \frac{1}{2}O_2 &\rightarrow CO \quad \Delta H_1 = -110 \text{ kJ} \\ CO + \frac{1}{2}O_2 &\rightarrow CO_2 \quad \Delta H_2 = -283 \text{ kJ} \end{align}$$ **Sum:** $$\Delta H_{total} = -110 + (-283) = -393 \text{ kJ}$$ --- ## Specific Heat Capacity $$\boxed{q = mc\Delta T}$$ Where: - $q$ = Heat energy (J) - $m$ = Mass (g) - $c$ = Specific heat capacity (J/g¬∞C) - $\Delta T$ = Temperature change (¬∞C) **Water:** $c = 4.18$ J/g¬∞C **Example:** Heat to warm 100g water by 10¬∞C $$q = 100 \times 4.18 \times 10 = 4180 \text{ J} = 4.18 \text{ kJ}$$ --- # ‚öñÔ∏è Chemical Equilibrium ## Equilibrium Constant For: $aA + bB \rightleftharpoons cC + dD$ $$\boxed{K_c = \frac{[C]^c[D]^d}{[A]^a[B]^b}}$$ **Interpretation:** - $K_c \gg 1$: Products favored - $K_c \ll 1$: Reactants favored - $K_c \approx 1$: Neither favored --- ## Le Chatelier's Principle **If stress applied, equilibrium shifts to relieve stress** **Effects:** **1. Concentration:** - Add reactant ‚Üí shifts right - Remove product ‚Üí shifts right **2. Pressure (gases):** - Increase pressure ‚Üí shifts to fewer moles side **3. Temperature:** - Exothermic: Heat increase ‚Üí shifts left - Endothermic: Heat increase ‚Üí shifts right --- # üåø Organic Chemistry ## Hydrocarbons ### Alkanes (Single bonds) **General formula:** $C_nH_{2n+2}$ **Examples:** - Methane: $CH_4$ - Ethane: $C_2H_6$ - Propane: $C_3H_8$ --- ### Alkenes (Double bond) **General formula:** $C_nH_{2n}$ **Examples:** - Ethene: $C_2H_4$

chunks.content: - Exothermic: Heat increase ‚Üí shifts left - Endothermic: Heat increase ‚Üí shifts right --- # üåø Organic Chemistry ## Hydrocarbons ### Alkanes (Single bonds) **General formula:** $C_nH_{2n+2}$ **Examples:** - Methane: $CH_4$ - Ethane: $C_2H_6$ - Propane: $C_3H_8$ --- ### Alkenes (Double bond) **General formula:** $C_nH_{2n}$ **Examples:** - Ethene: $C_2H_4$ or $CH_2=CH_2$ - Propene: $C_3H_6$ --- ### Alkynes (Triple bond) **General formula:** $C_nH_{2n-2}$ **Examples:** - Ethyne: $C_2H_2$ or $CH \equiv CH$ --- ## Functional Groups | Group | Formula | Example | |-------|---------|---------| | Alcohol | $-OH$ | Ethanol $CH_3CH_2OH$ | | Carboxylic acid | $-COOH$ | Acetic acid $CH_3COOH$ | | Aldehyde | $-CHO$ | Formaldehyde $HCHO$ | | Ketone | $-CO-$ | Acetone $(CH_3)_2CO$ | | Ester | $-COO-$ | Ethyl acetate $CH_3COOC_2H_5$ | --- # ‚ö° Electrochemistry ## Oxidation-Reduction (Redox) **Oxidation:** Loss of electrons $$\boxed{\text{OIL: Oxidation Is Loss}}$$ **Reduction:** Gain of electrons $$\boxed{\text{RIG: Reduction Is Gain}}$$ **Example:** $$Zn + Cu^{2+} \rightarrow Zn^{2+} + Cu$$ - $Zn$ loses 2$e^-$ ‚Üí **Oxidized** - $Cu^{2+}$ gains 2$e^-$ ‚Üí **Reduced** --- ## Oxidation Numbers **Rules:** 1. Free element: 0 2. Monatomic ion: Charge value 3. O in compounds: -2 (usually) 4. H in compounds: +1 (usually) 5. Sum = charge of molecule/ion --- ## Electrochemical Cells **Galvanic Cell:** Chemical ‚Üí Electrical energy (battery) **Electrolytic Cell:** Electrical ‚Üí Chemical energy (electrolysis) **Cell potential:** $$\boxed{E¬∞_{cell} = E¬∞_{cathode} - E¬∞_{anode}}$$ --- # üìä Periodic Table Trends ## Atomic Radius **Trend:** - **‚Üì Down group:** Increases (more shells) - **‚Üí Across period:** Decreases (more protons, same shells) --- ## Ionization Energy **Definition:** Energy to remove electron **Trend:** - **‚Üì Down group:** Decreases (electrons further) - **‚Üí Across period:** Increases (stronger attraction) --- ## Electronegativity **Trend:** - **‚Üì Down group:** Decreases - **‚Üí Across period:** Increases - **Highest:** F (Fluorine) = 4.0 --- # üíª Try These in Genius AI! **Open http://localhost:3000 and ask:** ### Basic Chemistry: ``` Explain atomic structure. Include protons, neutrons, electrons with charges and masses. Show notation for Carbon-12 in LaTeX. ``` ### Chemical Bonding: ``` What are the differences between ionic, covalent, and metallic bonding? Give examples with electron transfer/sharing diagrams. ``` ### Stoichiometry: ``` How many grams of CO2 are produced when 10g of CH4 burns completely? Show the balanced equation and all calculations in LaTeX. ``` ### pH Calculations: ``` Calculate the pH of a solution with [H+] = 2.5 √ó 10^-4 M. Show the formula and steps. Also find pOH. ``` ### Gas Laws: ``` A gas occupies 5L at 2 atm and 300K. What volume will it occupy at 1 atm and 400K? Use combined gas law with all steps. ``` ### Organic Chemistry: ``` Draw and explain the structural formulas for methane, ethane, and propane. Show their general alkane formula CnH2n+2. ``` --- # ‚ú® Why Use Genius AI for Chemistry? ‚úÖ **Beautiful LaTeX** - All equations rendered perfectly ‚úÖ **Step-by-step** - Every calculation shown clearly ‚úÖ **Comprehensive** - Up to 16K tokens (12,000+ words) ‚úÖ **Chain-of-thought** - Understand the reasoning ‚úÖ **All topics covered** -

chunks.content: # üéµ Music Theory Complete Guide ## Table of Contents 1. [Musical Staff & Clefs](#musical-staff--clefs) 2. [Notes & Pitch](#notes--pitch) 3. [Rhythm & Time](#rhythm--time) 4. [Scales & Keys](#scales--keys) 5. [Intervals](#intervals) 6. [Chords](#chords) 7. [Musical Terms](#musical-terms) --- # üéº Musical Staff & Clefs ## The Staff **Definition:** Five parallel horizontal lines where notes are written ``` Line 5 ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê Line 4 ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ Line 3 ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê Line 2 ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ Line 1 ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê ``` **Spaces:** Four spaces between the five lines **Ledger Lines:** Extra lines above/below staff for higher/lower notes --- ## Treble Clef (G Clef) üéª **Symbol:** ùÑû **Also called:** G clef (curls around G line) **Used for:** High-pitched instruments - Piano (right hand) - Violin - Flute - Trumpet - Soprano voice --- ### Treble Clef Notes **Lines (bottom to top):** ``` F ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 5) D ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 4) B ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 3) G ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 2) E ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 1) ``` **Mnemonic:** **E**very **G**ood **B**oy **D**oes **F**ine OR: **E**very **G**ood **B**oy **D**eserves **F**ruit --- **Spaces (bottom to top):** ``` E (Space 4) C (Space 3) A (Space 2) F (Space 1) ``` **Mnemonic:** **F A C E** (spells "FACE") --- **Complete Treble Clef:** ``` F (ledger line above) F ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 5) E (Space 4) D ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 4) C (Space 3) B ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 3) A (Space 2) G ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 2) F (Space 1) E ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 1) D (ledger line below) ``` --- ## Bass Clef (F Clef) üé∏ **Symbol:** ùÑ¢ **Also called:** F clef (two dots surround F line) **Used for:** Low-pitched instruments - Piano (left hand) - Bass guitar - Cello - Trombone - Bass voice --- ### Bass Clef Notes **Lines (bottom to top):** ``` A ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 5) F ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 4) D ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 3) B ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 2) G ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 1) ``` **Mnemonic:** **G**ood **B**oys **D**o **F**ine **A**lways OR: **G**reat **B**ig **D**ogs **F**ight **A**nimals --- **Spaces (bottom to top):** ``` G (Space 4) E (Space 3) C (Space 2) A (Space 1) ``` **Mnemonic:** **A**ll **C**ows **E**at **G**rass OR: **A**ll **C**ars **E**at **G**as --- **Complete Bass Clef:** ``` A (ledger line above) A ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 5) G (Space 4) F ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 4) E (Space 3) D ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 3) C (Space 2) B ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ (Line 2) A (Space 1) G ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê (Line 1) F (ledger line below) ``` --- ## Grand Staff (Piano) **Definition:** Treble and bass clefs together ``` Treble ùÑû Clef ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê F ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ D ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê B ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ G ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê E ----C (Middle C)---- ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê G Bass ùÑ¢ ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ B Clef ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê D ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ F ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê A ``` **Middle C:** The bridge between treble and bass --- # üéπ Notes & Pitch ## The Musical Alphabet **Letters:** A B C D E F G (then repeats) **Pattern:** ``` A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C ‚Üí D ‚Üí E ‚Üí F ‚Üí G ‚Üí A (octave higher) ``` --- ## Sharps (#) and Flats (‚ô≠) **Sharp (#):** Raises pitch by half step - C ‚Üí C# (C sharp) **Flat

chunks.content: A B C D E F G (then repeats) **Pattern:** ``` A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C ‚Üí D ‚Üí E ‚Üí F ‚Üí G ‚Üí A (octave higher) ``` --- ## Sharps (#) and Flats (‚ô≠) **Sharp (#):** Raises pitch by half step - C ‚Üí C# (C sharp) **Flat (‚ô≠):** Lowers pitch by half step - D ‚Üí D‚ô≠ (D flat) **Natural (‚ôÆ):** Cancels sharp or flat --- ## Chromatic Scale (All 12 notes) ``` C ‚Üí C#/D‚ô≠ ‚Üí D ‚Üí D#/E‚ô≠ ‚Üí E ‚Üí F ‚Üí F#/G‚ô≠ ‚Üí G ‚Üí G#/A‚ô≠ ‚Üí A ‚Üí A#/B‚ô≠ ‚Üí B ‚Üí C ``` **Note:** No sharps/flats between E-F and B-C --- ## Octaves **Definition:** Same note, 8 steps higher or lower **Example:** - Low C, Middle C, High C (all "C" but different pitches) **Frequency relationship:** - Octave higher = double frequency - Middle C = 261.63 Hz - C above Middle C = 523.25 Hz --- # ‚è±Ô∏è Rhythm & Time ## Note Values **Whole Note:** 4 beats ``` ùÖù (hollow oval) ``` **Half Note:** 2 beats ``` ùÖóùÖ• (hollow oval + stem) ``` **Quarter Note:** 1 beat ``` ‚ô© (filled oval + stem) ``` **Eighth Note:** 1/2 beat ``` ‚ô™ (filled oval + stem + flag) ``` **Sixteenth Note:** 1/4 beat ``` ‚ô¨ (filled oval + stem + 2 flags) ``` --- ## Rest Values **Whole Rest:** 4 beats ``` ‚ñ¨ (hangs below line) ``` **Half Rest:** 2 beats ``` ‚ñ¨ (sits on line) ``` **Quarter Rest:** 1 beat ``` ùÑΩ ``` **Eighth Rest:** 1/2 beat ``` ùÑæ ``` **Sixteenth Rest:** 1/4 beat ``` ùÑø ``` --- ## Time Signatures **Format:** ``` Top number = Beats per measure ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ Bottom number = Note value per beat ``` --- ### Common Time Signatures **4/4 (Common Time):** - 4 beats per measure - Quarter note gets one beat - **Most common** - Symbol: **C** **Example:** ``` | ‚ô© ‚ô© ‚ô© ‚ô© | 1 2 3 4 ``` --- **3/4 (Waltz Time):** - 3 beats per measure - Quarter note gets one beat - Waltz rhythm **Example:** ``` | ‚ô© ‚ô© ‚ô© | 1 2 3 ``` --- **2/4:** - 2 beats per measure - March rhythm --- **6/8:** - 6 beats per measure - Eighth note gets one beat - Feels like 2 groups of 3 **Example:** ``` | ‚ô™ ‚ô™ ‚ô™ | ‚ô™ ‚ô™ ‚ô™ | 1 2 3 4 5 6 ``` --- ## Dots and Ties **Dotted Note:** Adds half the note's value - Dotted half note = 2 + 1 = **3 beats** - Dotted quarter note = 1 + 0.5 = **1.5 beats** **Tie:** Connects two notes ``` ‚ô© ‚å¢ ‚ô© = 1 + 1 = 2 beats (held continuously) ``` --- # üéº Scales & Keys ## Major Scale **Pattern:** Whole - Whole - Half - Whole - Whole - Whole - Half **Abbreviation:** W W H W W W H **C Major Scale:** ``` C ‚Üí D ‚Üí E ‚Üí F ‚Üí G ‚Üí

C Major - A Minor **Order of Sharps:** F# C# G# D# A# E# B# **Mnemonic:** **F**ather **C**harles **G**oes **D**own **A**nd **E**nds **B**attle **Order of Flats:** B‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ D‚ô≠ G‚ô≠ C‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ **Mnemonic:** **B**attle **E**nds **A**nd **D**own **G**oes **C**harles' **F**ather --- ## Circle of Fifths **Major Keys (Clockwise):** ``` C (no #/‚ô≠) F (1‚ô≠) G (1#) B‚ô≠ (2‚ô≠) D (2#) E‚ô≠ (3‚ô≠) A (3#) A‚ô≠ (4‚ô≠) E (4#) D‚ô≠ (5‚ô≠) B (5#) G‚ô≠/F# (6‚ô≠/6#) ``` **Pattern:** Each key is 5 notes up from previous --- # üìè Intervals **Definition:** Distance between two notes ## Interval Numbers Count letter names (inclusive): - C to E = **3rd** (C-D-E) - C to G = **5th** (C-D-E-F-G) - C to C (octave) = **8th** --- ## Interval Quality ### Perfect Intervals - Unison (P1): Same note - Fourth (P4): 5 half steps - Fifth (P5): 7 half steps - Octave (P8): 12 half steps ### Major Intervals - Second (M2): 2 half steps - Third (M3): 4 half steps - Sixth (M6): 9 half steps - Seventh (M7): 11 half steps ### Minor Intervals - Minor = Major minus 1 half step - m2: 1 half step - m3: 3 half steps - m6: 8 half steps - m7: 10 half steps --- ## Consonance vs Dissonance **Consonant (Pleasant):** - Perfect intervals (P1, P4, P5, P8) - Major and minor 3rds and 6ths **Dissonant (Tense):** - Major and minor 2nds and 7ths - Augmented and diminished intervals --- # üé∏ Chords ## Triads (3-Note Chords) **Built:** Root + 3rd + 5th --- ### Major Triad **Pattern:** Root + M3 + P5 **C Major:** C - E - G - C to E = Major 3rd (4 half steps) - E to G = Minor 3rd (3 half steps) **Sound:** Happy, stable --- ### Minor Triad **Pattern:** Root + m3 + P5 **C Minor:** C - E‚ô≠ - G - C to E‚ô≠ = Minor 3rd (3 half steps) - E‚ô≠ to G = Major 3rd (4 half steps) **Sound:** Sad, stable --- ### Diminished Triad **Pattern:** Root + m3 + dim5 **C Diminished:** C - E‚ô≠
chunks.subject: Music Theory

chunks.content: Root + m3 + P5 **C Minor:** C - E‚ô≠ - G - C to E‚ô≠ = Minor 3rd (3 half steps) - E‚ô≠ to G = Major 3rd (4 half steps) **Sound:** Sad, stable --- ### Diminished Triad **Pattern:** Root + m3 + dim5 **C Diminished:** C - E‚ô≠ - G‚ô≠ **Sound:** Tense, unstable --- ### Augmented Triad **Pattern:** Root + M3 + Aug5 **C Augmented:** C - E - G# **Sound:** Bright, unstable --- ## Chord Progressions **Common Progressions:** **I-IV-V (1-4-5):** - In C Major: C - F - G - Most common in pop/rock **I-V-vi-IV (1-5-6-4):** - In C Major: C - G - Am - F - "Four Chord Song" progression **ii-V-I (2-5-1):** - Jazz progression - In C Major: Dm - G - C --- # üéº Musical Terms & Symbols ## Tempo (Speed) **Italian Terms:** - **Largo:** Very slow (40-60 BPM) - **Adagio:** Slow (66-76 BPM) - **Andante:** Walking pace (76-108 BPM) - **Moderato:** Moderate (108-120 BPM) - **Allegro:** Fast (120-168 BPM) - **Presto:** Very fast (168-200 BPM) **BPM:** Beats Per Minute --- ## Dynamics (Volume) **From quietest to loudest:** - **pp (pianissimo):** Very soft - **p (piano):** Soft - **mp (mezzo piano):** Medium soft - **mf (mezzo forte):** Medium loud - **f (forte):** Loud - **ff (fortissimo):** Very loud **Changes:** - **crescendo (cresc.):** Gradually louder (<) - **decrescendo (decresc.):** Gradually softer (>) --- ## Articulation **Staccato (¬∑):** Short, detached **Legato (‚å¢):** Smooth, connected **Accent (>):** Emphasized **Fermata (ùÑê):** Hold longer **Slur:** Curved line connecting notes (play smoothly) --- ## Repeat Signs **Repeat bars (|: :|):** Play section twice **1st & 2nd endings:** ``` |: measure :| 1. ending || 2. ending | ``` - First time: play 1st ending - Second time: skip to 2nd ending **D.C. (Da Capo):** Return to beginning **D.S. (Dal Segno):** Return to sign (ùÑã) **Fine:** End --- # üíª Try in Genius AI! **Open http://localhost:3000 and ask:** ### Clefs: ``` Explain the difference between treble clef and bass clef.
